data.title: NVIDIA: Jensen Just Raised The AI Bar (Again), Buy The Post-Earnings Dip
data.description:
NVIDIA (NVDA) popped, then dropped in the hours after reporting Q4 earnings on Wednesday, February 25. By the following morning, shares were down modestly, which seemed to counter what was a gangbuster set of revenue and profit figures. Free cash flow was also strong, as AI hyperscaler capex is NVIDIA’s gain.

Indeed, we are in a different environment compared to two or three years ago. The bar is simply higher for the world’s most valuable company. I had a "Buy" rating on NVDA back in January, following a generally successful CES. The stock, for now, remains below the top of a key trading range (which I will detail later), and NVIDIA’s GTC AI event is now in focus.

NVDA is up 8% since my previous analysis. Today, I reiterate a "Buy" rating and am raising my price target based on the robust Q4 numbers.

NVIDIA Leader to Laggard Lately

NVIDIA EPS Rising, Share Price Stalled

NVIDIA Has Moved Little After Recent Earnings Reports

In February, NVIDIA reported a strong set of quarterly results. Q4 non-GAAP EPS of $1.62 topped the Wall Street consensus forecast of $1.54, while revenue of $68.1 billion, up a whopping 73% from the same period last year, was a healthy $1.9 billion beat.

Jensen Huang’s company achieved record Data Center net sales, +22% sequentially and +75% YoY, with record firm-wide revenue of $215.9 billion for the full year. Guidance also blew past analysts’ expectations.

NVIDIA: Segment Results

Shares were down 3% by the following morning, marking yet another somewhat muted post-earnings performance. The options market had priced in a 7.5% earnings-related stock price swing based on the at-the-money straddle expiring this week. I expect implied volatility to cool from near 50% before the numbers hit to perhaps 30%-35% in the days ahead... but volatility may present itself in mid-March around the AI GTC event.

Looking back on the quarter that was, it was a record-breaking Q4 and year for the $4.8 trillion market cap company. The stellar growth was primarily driven by, of course, its Data Center segment, where revenue surged due to $51.3 billion in net sales from compute and $11.0 billion from networking. Jensen noted intense demand for the firm’s Blackwell, Hopper, and Ampere-based architectures.

NVIDIA: Revenue Highlights

NVIDIA's GAAP gross margin improved to 75.0%, and GAAP diluted EPS nearly doubled YoY to $1.76. Additionally, NVIDIA generated $34.9 billion in free cash flow and returned $8.1 billion to shareholders through stock repurchases and a small dividend.

Looking ahead to the first quarter of fiscal year 2027, the company anticipates further revenue growth to approximately $78.0 billion.

NVIDIA: Major FCF Growth

On the call, Jensen introduced a paradigm shift in how investors should view AI spending. He argued that for NVIDIA's customers, compute is no longer a cost center, but a revenue generator. Because of "token monetization," every dollar spent on a Blackwell or Rubin rack directly translates to the ability to sell AI tokens (inference). He noted that "the cash issues will be resolved by the cash flows of AI factories being much better than expected."

Now, Jensen is first and foremost an innovator, but he’s also a salesman. He centered on agentic AI when speaking with analysts. But along with the intriguing and inspiring narrative, the CEO confirmed that while the market is just beginning to digest Blackwell, NVIDIA has already shipped its first Vera Rubin samples to customers.

What’s more, the firm has diversified into so-called "Sovereign AI,” exposing itself to countries and not just the major domestic AI hyperscalers. This is a bullish factor that should sustain at least a market P/E multiple.

On the earnings outlook, EPS growth is expected to rise from $8.25 in the current fiscal year to above $10 in the out year. By FY 2029, NVIDIA could approach $13 in operating per-share earnings. With annual revenue gains and impressive operating leverage, the earnings picture remains sanguine.

Not surprisingly, we saw 21 sell side EPS upgrades in the previous 90 days, compared to just a trio of downgrades. Finally, profitability trends are likewise impressive, with free cash flow per share before the Q4 numbers of $3.17.

NVIDIA: Revenue & Earnings Forecasts, EPS Revision Trends

On valuation, I have updates to my previous numbers. If we assume $8.40 of forward 12-month non-GAAP EPS and apply a 28x multiple, then shares should trade near $235.

I increased the earnings assumption due to the period shift and Q4 beat, but lowered the multiple as the firm diversifies and amid slightly higher risks in the AI trade.

NVDA: Very Low PEG Ratio, Modest P/E

Key risks include a capex slowdown among the AI hyperscalers, given the big investment growth announced in recent weeks. The new tax policy incentivizes capex, and that may pull forward out-year AI projects.

More broadly, a global macroeconomic slowdown would likely reduce enterprise spending on AI, while increased competition from other global semiconductor companies will likely result in lower margins in the year ahead. The trade war appears to be a smaller risk today, but geopolitical risks remain elevated, which could impact the supply chain.

For sure, ASIC customer AI chip development from AI names is a possible risk, but NVIDIA continues to bring training and inference costs down, which helps defend NVIDIA's GPUs.

In the near term, reduced profitability among software companies could call into question the broader AI growth narrative.

Risk: NVIDIA Is Dependent on AI Hyperscaler Capex

Competitor Analysis

Looking ahead, corporate event data provided by Wall Street Horizon show a confirmed Q1 2027 earnings date of Wednesday, May 20 AMC. The company’s flagship GTC AI Conference takes place starting on Monday, March 16, so we could see added volatility that week.

Corporate Event Calendar

The Technical Take

With shares responding modestly positively to the Q4 report, NVDA’s technical situation may be turning more bullish. Notice in the chart below that the stock—trading at $190 as of this writing—may be poised to finally close above a key range dating back to November 10. The stock still has work to do, and the Friday (weekly) settle will be even more important. But should we get the breakout, then a measured move upside price objective of about $222 would be in play—just below my intrinsic value target.

But take a look at the RSI momentum oscillator at the top of the graph. It, like price, has been range bound. A share-price rally paired with an RSI breakout is what we want to see. The long-term 200-day moving average, meanwhile, remains on the rise, suggesting that the bulls control the primary trend. The stock did hit $207 right after the earnings report, while the all-time high of $212 is near-term resistance.

Assuming a breakout, $196 would become support (former resistance becomes new support). Longer-term support is down at $153.

NVDA: Bullish Upside Breakout Possible, Monitoring the RSI

The Bottom Line

I have a "Buy" rating on NVDA. Today, after the Q4 report, I am raising my price target and feel more confident that a technical breakout may soon occur.

data.title: Allspring SMID Cap Growth Fund Q4 2025 Commentary
data.description:
Quarterly review

  • The Allspring SMID Cap Growth Fund underperformed the Russell 2500 Growth Index benchmark during the fourth quarter.
  • Security selection within the industrials and information technology ('IT') sectors detracted from returns.
  • Select holdings within financials, consumer discretionary, and health care contributed positively to performance.

Market review - 2025 in review

U.S. equities delivered a third consecutive year of positive returns in 2025, with gains once again concentrated in growth-oriented parts of the market. Stocks in the IT and communication services sectors remained central to index performance as investors continued to reward companies positioned to capture outsized demand from the buildout of artificial intelligence ('AI')—particularly those showing business momentum and pricing power.

The year was also a reminder that markets can “climb a wall of worry” even when policy headlines are destabilizing. Early spring delivered the most dramatic test: The White House’s April 2 “Liberation Day” action jolted risk assets, reviving trade-war fears and forcing investors to reconsider inflation and margin assumptions. Over time, the tariff story became more iterative, marked by pauses and modifications that reduced the immediate sense of worst-case outcomes even as it remained a persistent overhang in corporate and consumer sentiment.

Fundamentals ultimately mattered more than headlines. Earnings tied to end markets with strong demand—especially AI—proved resilient, helping offset macroeconomic crosscurrents that ranged from trade policy and politics to immigration debates and gradually cooling labor markets. At the consumer level, conditions looked increasingly uneven: Higher-income households continued to spend, while middle- and lower-income cohorts showed clearer signs of trade-down behavior amid ongoing affordability pressure. Against that backdrop, market breadth improved episodically, but overall performance remained heavily influenced by a concentrated set of large-cap winners—an important context for assessing the outlook as we move forward.

Shifting leadership

AI was a key economic driver in 2025, and leadership broadened within the AI complex. What began as a narrow story dominated by a handful of mega-cap winners increasingly expanded into the infrastructure “picks and shovels” that enable AI deployment—spanning semiconductors, networking, data-center components, and adjacent software ecosystems. That evolution helped reinforce the market’s preference for companies able to convert AI enthusiasm into measurable bookings, backlog, and operating leverage.

At the same time, leadership outside the mega caps was more sensitive to rates and liquidity. As the Federal Reserve (Fed) shifted toward easing in September, risk appetite broadened and participation improved—most visibly in smaller-cap and more cyclically oriented areas. However, the quality of those rallies was mixed as some of the strongest upside phases were led by lower-quality and unprofitable companies, underscoring the difference between liquidity-driven beta surges and fundamentally supported returns. In our view, that distinction became one of the most important “fault lines” in the market and a key lens for evaluating opportunities into 2026.

Year-end cyclical rotation

The fourth quarter added fresh complexity to an already eventful year. Investor attention turned more intensely to the scale, timing, and funding of AI-related capital commitments, prompting renewed debate about whether expectations were running ahead of eventual monetization. This scrutiny contributed to another rotation away from the more crowded AI exposures and toward more cyclical and value-oriented positioning.

Macroeconomic uncertainty also rose during the quarter as the U.S. government shutdown disrupted portions of the data flow and added noise to near-term growth tracking. By late in the quarter, however, markets leaned back toward optimism as the shutdown ended and the Fed’s December messaging reinforced the easing trajectory that began in September, supporting a rebound in broader risk appetite into year-end.

Overall, most major U.S. equity indexes finished the fourth quarter higher while style leadership shifted: Value outperformed growth, reflecting the rotation away from the AI complex into more cyclical positions. The Russell 1000 Value Index returned 3.81% during the quarter, outperforming the Russell 1000 Growth Index’s return of 1.12% by nearly 270 basis points (bps; 100 bps equal 1.00%).

Fund performance and attribution

Top Contributors and Detractors to Quarter-End Fund Performance

CONTRIBUTORS

  • Teva Pharmaceutical Industries Ltd. Sponsored ADR (TEVA)
  • Guardant Health, Inc.
  • Carpenter Technology (CRS) Corp.
  • Natera, Inc. (NTRA)
  • ATI Inc. (ATI)

DETRACTORS

  • Bloom Energy Corp. Class A (BE)
  • Commvault Systems, Inc. (CVLT)
  • Varonis Systems, Inc. (VRNS)
  • Adtalem Global Education Inc. (ATGE)
  • Talen Energy Corp (TLN).
The holdings identified do not represent all of the securities purchased or sold during the period shown and should not be construed as a recommendation to purchase or sell a particular security. Information on calculation methodology and a list showing the overall contribution of each holding in the account for the period shown are available upon request.

Discussion of Contributors

The outlook is healthy for Teva Pharmaceutical Industries ('TEVA'). The recent quarter was a milestone for Teva Pharmaceuticals. Teva previously faced headwinds from declining generic sales and debt from past acquisitions. In early 2023, the company appointed a new CEO, marking a pivotal leadership change aimed at stabilizing operations, improving profitability, and reigniting growth. Under its “pivot to growth” strategy, Teva has expanded its biosimilars portfolio and strengthened its generics business, returning that segment to positive growth. However, the real engine of performance lies in Teva’s internally developed specialty medicines—AUSTEDO, AJOVY, and UZEDY—which are delivering robust revenue gains as adoption accelerates. In the latest quarter, Teva exceeded revenue expectations and achieved meaningful cost efficiencies, prompting Standard & Poor’s to upgrade its credit rating. We believe that with a growing pipeline of innovative treatments, disciplined financial management, and increasing market penetration, Teva is well positioned as a leading player in the global biopharmaceutical industry.

Carpenter Technology Corp. ('CRS') is prepared for lift-off. The company manufactures premium metal alloys used in highly specialized components across aerospace, medical, and industrial markets. While this diversification provides business stability, our investment thesis focuses on the significant replacement cycle in aerospace—a sector that has faced years of underinvestment and production delays. The post-pandemic surge in air travel has led airlines to keep aging fleets in service longer, driving higher maintenance needs. This has boosted demand for Carpenter’s suite of specialty bearings, fasteners, and electrical components.

Producing these advanced alloys is both complex and capital-intensive, giving Carpenter strong pricing power—a fact underscored this quarter as multiple long-term contracts were repriced favorably. With robust product demand and expanding margins, we remain confident in Carpenter’s long-term growth prospects.

Natera, Inc. ('NTRA'), is transforming cancer care. A molecular diagnostics company, Natera specializes in three main areas of health care: women’s health, oncology, and organ health. The women’s health division has dominant market share in noninvasive prenatal testing market, generating wide margins that have fueled innovation across other segments. Leveraging in-house expertise, Natera developed Signatera, a liquid biopsy that detects minimal residual disease and can identify cancer recurrence months before traditional methods. The blood-based test currently holds FDA and Medicare approvals for a modest number of cancer types, yet adoption has surged as doctors embrace the minimally invasive approach and early detection capabilities. With additional approvals pending, Natera is investing heavily to drive awareness and volumes in 2026. Backed by cutting-edge technology and a vast underpenetrated market, Natera, we believe, is well-positioned to transform cancer care for years to come.

Discussion of Detractors

AI concerns dented Commvault Systems, Inc. ('CVLT'). Commvault specializes in cyber security, housing complete backups of operating systems that provide companies with the opportunity to revert to prior versions in the event of cyberattacks. Once known for legacy backup solutions, Commvault has successfully pivoted toward subscription-based and software-as-a-service (SaaS) offerings. However, the recent quarter produced mixed financial results with positive new business growth yet contracting profit margins. Despite management signaling confidence in future execution, the rise of AI has caused intense scrutiny on potential disruption in the software industry. As a result, shares of Commvault sold off over the profitability concerns. Given heightened volatility and deteriorating visibility, we exited the position in favor of higher-conviction opportunities.

Varonis Systems, Inc. ('VRNS'), struggled to transform. Varonis specializes in data security software that helps organizations manage access controls and permissions across sensitive files and applications. Like many software peers, Varonis has aggressively shifted from on-premises solutions to a SaaS-first model. While cloud adoption has accelerated and now represents nearly three-quarters of revenue, the company has struggled to convert existing on-premise clients. Term license renewals plunged during the quarter and maintenance revenue fell by almost 50%, reflecting churn among legacy clients. The company trimmed full-year revenue guidance after these execution challenges along with a weaker outlook for federal government contracts. Considering these headwinds, our sell discipline was triggered as the fundamental thesis became challenged.

Adtalem Global Education Inc. ('ATGE') had a weak report card.

Adtalem is a leading education provider with top-tier health care universities, including Chamberlain University —the largest nursing degree provider in the U.S.—as well as several medical and veterinary programs. During the quarter, the company reported strong growth in revenue and reaffirmed full-year guidance.

However, shares came under pressure when management flagged operational execution issues in its largest segment and announced leadership changes to improve oversight, signaling concern over future enrollment trajectory. In light of this, we exited our position in favor of higher-conviction opportunities.

Fund positioning and outlook

Two big narratives

For U.S. equity investors, 2025 will be remembered for two key themes. First, AI continued to seize the spotlight. A super cycle of AI-related investments, which many expected to cool, went into higher gear. The arms race for computing power and infrastructure contributed to prolonged market concentration around leading large-cap technology stocks. The notion that AI would transcend into a broader subset of sectors was largely delayed. Despite the excitement, the year ended with concerns of a potential AI bubble driven by large “circular deals,” rising levels of both public and private debt, and a change in leadership for the market’s favored AI complex.

The second major theme of the year was around leadership from low-quality “non-earners.” “Risk-on” speculation was on the rise, largely driven by fading trade-war fears and an expectation of significant policy stimulus in 2026. The Fed was expected to continue to cut rates and shift in a dovish direction. Additionally, stimulative impacts from the One Big Beautiful Bill were expected to be a tailwind to economic growth.

Quality growth on sale

These factors contributed to the year ending with a divergence in market leadership. Value-oriented and economically sensitive stocks rallied in the fourth quarter, with higher-quality growth stocks generally lagging. The low-quality momentum, which was previously driven by themes like crypto and quantum computing, continued in the fourth quarter but with a different complexion. The darlings of retail traders shifted to commodities, transports, and speculative names in biotechnology.

This speculation resulted in some high-quality growth businesses going on sale. Sitting outside the current zeitgeist, there was a narrowing of the valuation premium awarded to companies that can grow sustainably at faster rates. Based on our experience, this setup is often favorable for future returns. When elite growth franchises de-rate on sentiment factors, compelling entry points can emerge. As the influence of sentiment diminishes over time, the underlying growth of the business reemerges as the dominant driver of returns.

With some portfolio holdings going unrewarded for exceptional fundamental results, we are excited at the prospects of strong future returns for these exceptional businesses.

Along the same lines, we remain excited about the emergence of small- and mid-cap equities. While market broadening took on a start/stop pattern, we expect a more sustained leadership shift in 2026. The setup for small- and mid-cap growth stocks remains highly favorable. Relative valuations are historically attractive, earnings growth is expected to close in on large caps, AI-related opportunities are broadening, corporate activity is picking up, and stimulative policy effects are in the system. The stars may be aligning for a period of healthy performance beyond the mega caps dominating U.S. equity benchmarks.

Scarcity of growth

We continue to have high conviction in the scarcity of growth. Unlike the consensus view that economic growth is about to reaccelerate, our view is that growth will remain at modest levels. From the bigger picture, we see structural forces compressing economic output. With only a small number of companies in U.S. equity benchmarks expected to deliver strong future earnings growth, companies with robust fundamentals will remain in short supply. This should benefit quality growth stocks as investors reward companies with sustainable fundamentals.

In closing, our approach is to remain highly disciplined. Rather than chasing short-term speculation, our focus is on identifying the true long-term winners of innovation such as AI, many of which will soon emerge beyond the infrastructure phase. We execute this strategy through stock selection, balanced portfolio construction, and a thoughtful approach to risk management. With economic growth slowing while technological disruption accelerates, focusing on resilient growth businesses on the “right side of change”—one company at a time—remains the cornerstone of our strategy.

Rather than chasing short-term speculation, our focus is on identifying the true long-term winners of innovation such as AI, many of which will soon emerge beyond the infrastructure phase.

Benchmark Descriptions:

The Russell 2500™ Growth Index measures the performance of those Russell 2500 companies with higher price/book ratios and higher forecasted growth values. You cannot invest directly in an index.

The Russell 1000® Value Index measures the performance of those Russell 1000 companies with lower price/book ratios and lower forecasted growth values. You cannot invest directly in an index.

The Russell 1000® Growth Index measures the performance of those Russell 1000 companies with higher price/book ratios and higher forecasted growth values. You cannot invest directly in an index.

The Lipper averages are compiled by Lipper, Inc., an independent mutual fund research and rating service. Each Lipper average represents a universe of funds that are similar in investment objective. You cannot invest directly in a Lipper average.

The Morningstar Category average is the average return for the peer group based on the returns of each individual fund within the group. The total return of the Morningstar Category average does not include the effect of sales charges. You cannot invest directly in a Morningstar Category average.

Diversification does not ensure or guarantee better performance and cannot eliminate the risk of investment losses.

Attribution Analysis:

Performance attribution and sector returns are calculated using the Brinson-Fachler attribution model. As such, performance attribution calculations may differ from the fund's actual investment results. Common sources of attribution dispersion from official returns include: the use of end of day holdings and prices, the exclusion of fees, and the use of myriad pricing sources to accommodate different benchmark providers.

Definition of Terms:

Active share of an account is calculated by subtracting a portfolio's overlap with its performance benchmark from 100%. The portfolio-level overlap compares parent-level weights between positions held in both the portfolio and benchmark, summing the lesser of such weights.

Alpha measures the difference between a fund's actual returns and its expected performance given its level of risk (as measured by beta).

Beta measures fund volatility relative to general market movements. It is a standardized measure of systematic risk in comparison with a specified index. The benchmark beta is 1.00 by definition.

Downside capture measures a fund's replication of its benchmark during periods of negative returns. During periods of negative benchmark returns, a downside capture ratio less than 100% reflects product performance greater than the benchmark and a downside capture ratio greater than 100% reflects performance less than the benchmark.

Information ratio measures the consistency of excess return (return in excess of a benchmark). This value is determined by taking the annualized excess return over a benchmark (style benchmark by default) and dividing it by the standard deviation of excess return.

Long-term growth forecast is the annual earnings-per-share growth that the company can sustain over the next 3 or 5 years based on Allspring estimate data.

Price/earnings to growth ratio (PEG ratio) uses long-term earnings growth estimates. The long-term earnings growth is the annual earnings-per-share growth that the company can sustain over the next 3 or 5 years based on estimate data.

R-squared is a measurement of how similar a fund's historical performance has been to that of the benchmark. The measure ranges from 0.0, which means that the fund's performance bears no relationship to the performance of the index, to 1.0, which means that the fund's performance was perfectly synchronized with the performance of the benchmark.

Sharpe ratio measures the potential reward offered by a mutual fund relative to its risk level. The ratio uses a fund's standard deviation and its excess return to determine reward per unit of risk. The higher the Sharpe ratio, the better the fund's historical risk-adjusted performance.

Standard deviation represents the degree to which an investment's performance has varied from its average performance over a particular time period.

Tracking error measures the extent to which a manager's performance mimics that of a benchmark. The value is the standard deviation of the difference between a fund's performance and a benchmark's performance.

Upside capture measures a fund's replication of its benchmark during periods of positive returns. During periods of positive benchmark returns, an upside capture ratio greater than 100% reflects product performance greater than the benchmark and an upside capture ratio less than 100% reflects performance less than the benchmark.

Risks: Investing involves risk, including the possible loss of principal. Stock values fluctuate in response to the activities of individual companies and general market and economic conditions. Smaller company stocks tend to be more volatile and less liquid than those of larger companies. Consult the fund's prospectus for additional information on these and other risks.

The Morningstar Rating for funds, or star rating, is calculated for managed products (including mutual funds, variable annuity and variable life subaccounts, exchange-traded funds, closed-end funds, and separate accounts) with at least a three-year history. Exchange-traded funds and open-ended mutual funds are considered a single population for comparative purposes. It is calculated based on a Morningstar risk-adjusted return measure that accounts for variation in a managed product's monthly excess performance, placing more emphasis on downward variations and rewarding consistent performance. The Morningstar Rating does not include any adjustment for sales loads. The top 10% of products in each product category receive 5 stars, the next 22.5% receive 4 stars, the next 35% receive 3 stars, the next 22.5% receive 2 stars, and the bottom 10% receive 1 star. The Overall Morningstar Rating for a managed product is derived from a weighted average of the performance figures associated with its 3-, 5-, and 10-year (if applicable) Morningstar Rating metrics. The weights are: 100% 3-year rating for 36–59 months of total returns, 60% 5-year rating/40% 3-year rating for 60–119 months of total returns, and 50% 10-year rating/30% 5-year rating/20% 3-year rating for 120 or more months of total returns. While the 10-year overall star rating formula seems to give the most weight to the 10-year period, the most recent 3-year period actually has the greatest impact because it is included in all three rating periods.

Across U.S.-domiciled mid-cap growth funds, the SMID Cap Growth Fund received 3 stars among 472 funds, 1 star among 446 funds, and 2 stars among 371 funds for the 3-, 5-, and 10-year periods, respectively. The Morningstar Rating is for the Institutional Class only; other classes may have different performance characteristics.

data.title: Nvidia Down Again On Earnings; AI Mentions Also Down
data.description:
Nvidia (NVDA) is down 5% today following yet another earnings triple play after the close yesterday. Barring a massive turnaround in the last hour of trading, this will be the seventh straight quarter where NVDA shares fell from the open to the close of trading on the day after it reports earnings.

Below is a snapshot of NVDA quarterly earnings versus estimates since ChatGPT's release at the end of 2022. Out of 13 total quarterly reports, NVDA has reported ten triple plays (beat EPS, beat sales, raised guidance).

In its first six earnings reports following the release of ChatGPT, NVDA shares averaged a one-day gain of 10% on its earnings reaction day. Following its last seven reports, though, shares have averaged a decline of 3% for an overall average of 3.2%.

Now that NVDA has reported and completed its conference call, we can update our chart of "AI" mentions from the mega-cap hyperscalers this earnings season.

Across the conference calls of Apple (AAPL), Amazon (AMZN), Alphabet (GOOG) (GOOGL), Meta (META), Microsoft (MSFT), and Nvidia, "AI" was mentioned 348 times this quarter. As shown below, that's down quite a bit from the 401 "AI" mentions last quarter, and it's 102 fewer than the peak "AI" reached during the Q1 2025 earnings season.

Below is a breakdown of "AI" mentions by stock going back to 2001. This quarter, Amazon and Apple were the only two that mentioned "AI" more on conference calls, with AMZN mentioning it a record 61 times.

META mentioned AI just 45 times, the lowest since Q4 2023, while NVDA's 82 mentions were the lowest since the last earnings season before ChatGPT's release!
